Title: The Tao is Like a Bow ï½œ Tao Te Ching Chapter 77 Explained

Content.Knowledge Point: The Tao of Heaven is like the bending of a bow, bringing balance through giving and taking.
Content.Text: The Tao of Heaven is like the bending of a bow. What is high is brought down. What is low is sent high. What's excessive is reduced. What's insufficient is increased. The Tao of Heaven takes from those who have too much and gives to those who are in want.

Content.Knowledge Point: The people's way is opposite, taking from the needy and giving to the wealthy.
Content.Text: The people's way is not like that. They take from those who are in want and give to those who have too much.

Content.Knowledge Point: Only those aligned with Tao can share abundantly with the world.
Content.Text: Yet who is able to have enough to give it to the world? Only the one who has Tao.

Content.Knowledge Point: The sage acts without seeking praise or recognition, focusing on emulating Tao.
Content.Text: Therefore, the sage toils but expects no praise. He does his work but does not dwell on it. He does not wish to make a display of his merit.

Content.Knowledge Point: Sharing one's abundance with others is a way to emulate Tao.
Content.Text: We've talked a lot in this series so far about how the sage takes the needs of others and treats them like his or her own. Lao Tzu speaks of the bending of a bow. When a bow is drawn, the top and bottom are both drawn toward the middle. What is high is made low and what is low is made high.

Content.Knowledge Point: Sharing one's abundance with others is a way to emulate Tao.
Content.Text: I don't think this image is only some kind of economic theory. While this idea certainly can't apply to helping those who are economically disadvantaged, it can apply to everything we do. Whatever we have a lot of, whether that be money, talent, knowledge, even humor, we can share this gift with others.

Content.Knowledge Point: The question of whether anyone can share abundantly with the world.
Content.Text: Everyone has something more abundantly than those around him or her. Whatever it is we are abundant in, these things have value to others and should be shared. With all that said, Lao Tzu poses this question. Is there anybody who has abundantly enough to share their excess with the whole world? Is this even possible?

Content.Knowledge Point: Only those aligned with Tao can share abundantly with the world.
Content.Text: It is only possible, he claims, if such a person is one with Tao. Anyone else who seeks to change the entire world will probably cause more harm than good.

Content.Knowledge Point: The sage understands the importance of aligning with Tao and sharing abundantly.
Content.Text: The Tao is the only thing that can supply enough excess for the entire world to benefit from. To think that we can do this on our own is foolishness. The sage understands this.

Content.Knowledge Point: The sage acts without seeking praise or recognition, focusing on emulating Tao.
Content.Text: Thus, he or she is focused on being one with Tao. And when this is done, he enjoys the increased capacity that the Tao brings. Because he does not desire to have more than others, he is not concerned with praise or taking credit for what he does.

Content.Knowledge Point: The sage's motivation is to emulate Tao, not impress others.
Content.Text: When he has done a task, he takes joy in it and then moves on to the next task. His motivation is not to impress others, but to emulate Tao.
